title: Poetry's Purpose
author: Emily Dickinson
content: I dwell in possibility.

title: Darkness Visible
author: John Milton
content: The mind is its own place.

title: The Road Less Traveled
author: Robert Frost
content: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood.

title: Hope and Feathers
author: Emily Dickinson
content: Hope is the thing with feathers that perches in the soul.
source: Hope is the thing with feathers

title: Nature's First Green
author: Robert Frost
content: Nature's first green is gold, her hardest hue to hold.

title: Death and the Maiden
author: Emily Dickinson
content: Because I could not stop for Death, he kindly stopped for me.
source: Because I could not stop for Death

title: The Human Condition
author: William Shakespeare
content: All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players.

title: Mortality's Shadow
author: William Shakespeare
content: To be or not to be, that is the question whether 'tis nobler.

title: Time's Passage
author: Andrew Marvell
content: Had we but world enough and time, this coyness, lady, were no crime.

title: Love's Philosophy
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
content: The fountains mingle with the river, and the rivers with the ocean.

title: Ozymandias
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
content: Look on my works, ye mighty, and despair! Nothing beside remains around the decay.

title: The Tiger's Fire
author: William Blake
content: Tiger, tiger, burning bright in the forests of the night, what immortal hand or eye could frame thy fearful symmetry?

title: Daffodils Dancing
author: William Wordsworth
content: I wandered lonely as a cloud that floats on high o'er vales and hills, when all at once I saw a crowd, a host of golden daffodils.
source: I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud

title: The Raven's Call
author: Edgar Allan Poe
content: Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary, over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore, while I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping.

title: Autumn's Glory
author: John Keats
content: Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness, close bosom-friend of the maturing sun; conspiring with him how to load and bless with fruit the vines that round the thatch-eaves run.

title: Dover Beach
author: Matthew Arnold
content: The sea is calm tonight. The tide is full, the moon lies fair upon the straits; on the French coast the light gleams and is gone; the cliffs of England stand, glimmering and vast, out in the tranquil bay.

title: Ulysses' Journey
author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
content: It little profits that an idle king, by this still hearth, among these barren crags, matched with an aged wife, I mete and dole unequal laws unto a savage race, that hoard, and sleep, and feed, and know not me.

title: Paradise Lost
author: John Milton
content: The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven. What matter where, if I be still the same, and what I should be, all but less than he whom thunder hath made greater?

title: The Waste Land
author: T.S. Eliot
content: April is the cruellest month, breeding lilacs out of the dead land, mixing memory and desire, stirring dull roots with spring rain. Winter kept us warm, covering earth in forgetful snow, feeding a little life with dried tubers.

title: Do Not Go Gentle
author: Dylan Thomas
content: Do not go gentle into that good night, old age should burn and rave at close of day; rage, rage against the dying of the light. Though wise men at their end know dark is right, because their words had forked no lightning they do not go gentle into that good night.
source: Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night
